Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186 § 14, provides that any landlord or person acting on behalf of a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant's quiet enjoyment of the leased premises is liable for actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.

105 CMR \u00a7 410.000.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the persistent water intrusion at the Premises interfered with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the property and created unsafe and unsanitary living conditions in violation of the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR § 410.000).

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: A landlord’s failure to address water intrusion and maintain premises in compliance with the state sanitary code constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely links the landlord’s statutory duty to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions under the State Sanitary Code with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment rights under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It holds that Gem’s failure to maintain the apartment in sanitary, watertight condition—despite repeated flooding—both breached the warranty of habitability and constituted an interference with quiet enjoyment under the statute. The reasoning explicitly relies on the sanitary code requirement that apartments be watertight and concludes that permitting repeated flooding that violates those standards is actionable as interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt:
“Further, a section of the State Sanitary Code (received in evidence), provides that apartments must be watertight. 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1978). In light of our decisions holding landlords responsible for injuries resulting from breaches of sanitary code provisions, Gem’s behavior was a sufficiently ‘proximate’ cause to justify the imposition of liability…
…Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Dartmouth v. Greater Boston Real Estate.raw_text: *Dartmouth v. Greater Boston Real Estate Bd.*, 407 Mass. 279 (1990)
*Dartmouth v. Greater Boston Real Estate.proposition: A landlord’s failure to address water intrusion and maintain premises in compliance with the state sanitary code constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
*Dartmouth v. Greater Boston Real Estate.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case involving murder and rape, focusing on grand jury procedure and jury instructions on manslaughter and criminal responsibility. It does not address landlord-tenant law, the state sanitary code, water intrusion, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about a landlord’s failure to address water intrusion constituting a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the persistent water intrusion at the Premises interfered with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the property and created unsafe and unsanitary living conditions in violation of the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR § 410.000).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses numerous severe sanitary code violations in a rental unit and affirms liability under theories including breach of the implied warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not specifically address “persistent water intrusion” or analyze water leaks as the basis for liability. Nor does it tie its holding to 105 CMR § 410.000 by name in connection with water intrusion. Thus, while it is generally supportive of claims based on unsanitary, unsafe conditions and interference with quiet enjoyment, it does not directly support the precise proposition about failure to remedy persistent water intrusion violating the State Sanitary Code.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.… The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects… Later that month, the Boston inspection services department served Haddad with three separate notices of violations of State and city housing regulations related to the condition of Gonzalez’s apartment.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.proposition: Defendant’s inaction and subsequent retaliation following Plaintiff’s lawful exercise of their right to seek municipal inspection further constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.support_reasoning: The opinion does support that a landlord’s inaction in the face of serious third‑party misconduct on common areas can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. However, it does not address or base liability on any "retaliation" by the landlord for a tenant’s exercise of a right to seek municipal inspection or similar governmental help. The holding is grounded in failure to take reasonable measures to remove unlawful actors, not in retaliatory conduct following a protected activity, so the proposition overstates what the case decides.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s inaction and subsequent retaliation following Plaintiff’s lawful exercise of their right to seek municipal inspection further constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion never discusses the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor any landlord retaliation or inaction following the tenant’s request for a municipal or housing inspection. The issues addressed are security deposit violations, rent control overcharges, warranty of habitability, utilities obligations under the sanitary code, and c. 93A inapplicability. Because the decision does not analyze retaliation or quiet enjoyment, it does not support the claimed proposition.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.
